data.title: Jamieson Talks Fake News and Civics at Ninth Circuit Session and at Steamboat
data.meta_description: APPC director Kathleen Hall Jamieson moderated panels on civics and fake news at the Ninth Circuit Judicial Conference, and kicked off a seminar series in Steamboat Springs, Colo., with a keynote on fake news.
data.meta_site_name: The Annenberg Public Policy Center of the University of Pennsylvania
data.text:
Annenberg Public Policy Center (APPC) director Kathleen Hall Jamieson moderated panels on civics and fake news at the Ninth Circuit Judicial Conference in San Francisco, a week after kicking off a seminar series in Steamboat Springs, Colo., with a talk on fake news.

The July 20 panel on fake news, “Lies, Damn Lies, and the News? Fake News: What It Is, What It Means, and Why It Matters,” was introduced by Hon. John B. Owens, Circuit Judge, U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, and featured Paul Singh Grewal, deputy general counsel for Facebook; commentator and radio host Hugh Hewitt; Slate senior editor Dahlia Lithwick; and Susan Weiner, general counsel for NBCUniversal news group.

Jamieson discussed the dangers of fake news in the political world and beyond, as well as her proposed alternate term: “viral deception,” or V.D. As reported by Courthouse News Service, she explained that with fake news, just like with venereal disease, “we need to be clear that you do not want to catch it, you do not want to transmit it and we’d like to say it’s been eradicated.” The panel discussed the implications of fake news on electoral politics, as well as in the business sector and in national security.

In moderating the July 17 panel on civics education, Jamieson highlighted both the APPC-sponsored Civics Renewal Network, a consortium of 31 nonprofit, nonpartisan organizations dedicated to strengthening civics education, and the educational materials created by APPC’s Leonore Annenberg Institute for Civics, such as the videos, guides, timelines and lesson plans available at Annenberg Classroom.The one-hour, 15-minute panel titled “Civics Education in the Ninth Circuit and Beyond” featured (below left-to-right): Hon. Sidney R. Thomas, Chief Judge, U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit; Hon. Neil M. Gorsuch, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court; Hon. Robert A. Katzmann, Chief Judge, U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit; Hon. Marilyn L. Huff, Senior District Court Judge and President of the Federal Judges Association; and Hon. Michael J. Newman, Magistrate Judge, Southern District of Ohio and President of the Federal Bar Association. Watch a full video of the panel below:

In an exchange reported by the Courthouse News Service, Jamieson noted that a 2016 APPC survey found that only a quarter of the American public can name all three branches of government – legislative, executive and judicial. Gorsuch and others said that a lack of civics knowledge should serve as a reminder that democracy relies on an informed citizenry. “It’s a really healthy reminder that self-government is not self-sustaining or self-perpetuating, but depends on all of us playing a role to keep it,” Gorsuch said, according to the news service.

Jamieson asked Gorsuch what part of the court system is poorly understood. He said the extent to which judges find consensus is vastly undercovered by the press and underappreciated by the public. He noted that the Supreme Court, with nine justices nominated by six different presidents, manages to make unanimous decisions more than 40 percent of the time, according to the news service.

Seminars at Steamboat

A week earlier, on July 10, Jamieson’s talk on “Debunking Political Deception and Viral Deception,” kicked off the 15th anniversary season of the Seminars at Steamboat in Steamboat Springs, Colo., which aims to “bring experts on a wide range of public policy topics to the Steamboat community.”

Jamieson’s talk touched on the reasoning behind the term “viral deception,” as well as her desire to improve the public’s ability both to recognize viral deception and to acknowledge their own vulnerability to it. She noted the importance of recognizing that people tend to regard messages more favorably when they come from like-minded individuals. About one in four people, she said, has reported sharing fabricated news. To uncover deception in political ads and elsewhere, it is critical to look at patterns of deception, because “when you recognize the pattern, when you see the first inaccurate statement, you think, ‘deceptive.’ ”

The talk also touched on the prevalence of viral deception in social media and online news, and how companies like Facebook and Google are working to fight it, with the help of FactCheck.org, an APPC project co-founded by Jamieson.
